answer_html: \(t \approx -1.578\) Therefore, the police arrived (ln(3/4))/(ln(5/6)) hours after the murder, that is, roughly an hour and a half.
answer_latex:
$t \approx -1.578$ Therefore, the police arrived (ln(3/4))/(ln(5/6)) hours after the
murder, that is, roughly an hour and a half.
hints_html:
Recall that Newton’s Law of Cooling states that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle T(t)=T_a+(T_0-T_a)e^{-kt}\end{aligned}\]

where Ta is the temperature of the environment; T0 is the initial temperature of the object; and T(t) is the temperature of the object at time t.
hints_latex:
Recall that Newton's Law of Cooling states that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
T(t)=T_a+(T_0-T_a)e^{-kt}
\end{align*} where \emph{T}\textsubscript{a} is the
temperature of the environment; \emph{T}\textsubscript{0} is the initial
temperature of the object; and \emph{T}(\emph{t}) is the temperature of
the object at time \emph{t}.
hints_raw:
Recall that Newton's Law of Cooling states that
:<math>\displaystyle
T(t)=T_a+(T_0-T_a)e^{-kt}
</math>
where ''T''<sub>a</sub> is the temperature of the environment; ''T''<sub>0</sub> is the initial temperature of the object; and ''T''(''t'') is the temperature of the object at time ''t''.
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
Newton’s Law of Cooling which states that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle T(t)=T_a+(T_0-T_a)e^{-kt}.\end{aligned}\]

Here, the initial temperature of the body T0 is 33\(^{\circ}\)C; the temperature of the environment Ta is given to be 21\(^{\circ}\)C; and the temperature of the body after 1 hour (T(1)) is 31\(^{\circ}\)C. Plugging in these numbers give us

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 31=21+(33-21)e^{-k}\end{aligned}\]

Using this equation, we can solve for k:

\[\begin{aligned} e^{-k} &=\frac{31-21}{33-21}=\frac{5}{6} \\ -k &=\ln(5/6) \\ k &=-\ln(5/6) \end{aligned}\]

And so now we have found the equation that gives us the temperature of the body at any time t:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle T(t) = 21 + 12e^{t\ln(5/6)}\end{aligned}\]

and we would like to know the time of death, which is the time at which the body temperature was 37\(^{\circ}\)C. For this, we simply solve

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle T(t) = 37\end{aligned}\]

that is

\[\begin{aligned} 21 + 12e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 37 \\ 12e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 16 \\ e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 16/12 \\ t\ln(5/6) &= \ln(4/3) \\ t &= \frac{\ln(4/3)}{\ln(5/6)} \\ t &\approx -1.578\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, the police arrived (ln(3/4))/(ln(5/6)) hours after the murder, that is, roughly an hour and a half.
sols_latex:
Newton's Law of Cooling which states that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
T(t)=T_a+(T_0-T_a)e^{-kt}.
\end{align*} Here, the initial temperature of the body
\emph{T}\textsubscript{0} is 33$^{\circ}$C; the temperature of the
environment \emph{T}\textsubscript{a} is given to be 21$^{\circ}$C; and
the temperature of the body after 1 hour (\emph{T}(1)) is 31$^{\circ}$C.
Plugging in these numbers give us

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
31=21+(33-21)e^{-k}
\end{align*} Using this equation, we can solve for \emph{k}:

\begin{align*}
e^{-k} &=\frac{31-21}{33-21}=\frac{5}{6} \\
-k &=\ln(5/6) \\
k &=-\ln(5/6) 
\end{align*}

And so now we have found the equation that gives us the temperature of
the body at any time \emph{t}:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
T(t) = 21 + 12e^{t\ln(5/6)}
\end{align*} and we would like to know the time of
death, which is the time at which the body temperature was
37$^{\circ}$C. For this, we simply solve

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
T(t) = 37
\end{align*} that is

\begin{align*}
21 + 12e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 37 \\
12e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 16 \\
e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 16/12 \\
t\ln(5/6) &= \ln(4/3) \\
t &= \frac{\ln(4/3)}{\ln(5/6)} \\
t &\approx -1.578
\end{align*}

Therefore, the police arrived (ln(3/4))/(ln(5/6)) hours after the
murder, that is, roughly an hour and a half.
sols_raw:
Newton's Law of Cooling which states that
:<math>\displaystyle
T(t)=T_a+(T_0-T_a)e^{-kt}
</math>.
Here, the initial temperature of the body ''T''<sub>0</sub> is 33°C; the temperature of the environment ''T''<sub>a</sub> is given to be 21°C; and the temperature of the body after 1 hour (''T''(1)) is 31°C.
Plugging in these numbers give us
:<math>\displaystyle
31=21+(33-21)e^{-k}
</math>
Using this equation, we can solve for ''k'':
:<math>
\begin{align}
e^{-k} & =\frac{31-21}{33-21}=\frac{5}{6} \\
-k & =\ln(5/6) \\
k & =-\ln(5/6) \\
\end{align}
</math>

And so now we have found the equation that gives us the temperature of the body at any time ''t'':
:<math>\displaystyle
T(t) = 21 + 12e^{t\ln(5/6)}
</math>
and we would like to know the time of death, which is the time at which the body temperature was 37°C. For this, we simply solve
:<math>\displaystyle
T(t) = 37
</math>
that is
:<math>\begin{align}
21 + 12e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 37 \\
12e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 16 \\
e^{t\ln(5/6)} &= 16/12 \\
t\ln(5/6) &= \ln(4/3) \\
t &= \frac{\ln(4/3)}{\ln(5/6)} \\
t &\approx -1.578
\end{align}</math>

Therefore, the police arrived (ln(3/4))/(ln(5/6)) hours after the murder, that is, roughly an hour and a half.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.

A wealthy man was found murdered in his home. The police arrived on scene at 10:00 P.M. The temperature of the body at 10:00 P.M. was 33\(^{\circ}\)C and one hour later it was 31\(^{\circ}\)C. The temperature of the room in which the body was found was 21\(^{\circ}\)C and normal body temperature is 37\(^{\circ}\)C. Assume that the body cools after death according to Newton’s Law of Cooling.

How many hours before the police arrived on the scene did the murder occur?
statement_latex:
\emph{\textbf{Full-Solution Problems.} In questions 2-8, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work.} If a box is provided, write
your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required
unless explicitly stated.}

A wealthy man was found murdered in his home. The police arrived on
scene at 10:00 P.M. The temperature of the body at 10:00 P.M. was
33$^{\circ}$C and one hour later it was 31$^{\circ}$C. The temperature
of the room in which the body was found was 21$^{\circ}$C and normal
body temperature is 37$^{\circ}$C. Assume that the body cools after
death according to Newton's Law of Cooling.

How many hours before the police arrived on the scene did the murder
occur?
statement_raw:
'''''Full-Solution Problems.''' In questions 2-8, justify your answers and '''show all your work.''' If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.''

A wealthy man was found murdered in his home. The police arrived on scene at 10:00 P.M. The temperature of the body at 10:00 P.M. was 33°C and one hour later it was 31°C. The temperature of the room in which the body was found was 21°C and normal body temperature is 37°C. Assume that the body cools after death according to Newton's Law of Cooling.

How many hours before the police arrived on the scene did the murder occur?
